subCategories.title: Overview
subCategories.description: Description of this sub Category

subCategories.title: Accessability
subCategories.description: ILIAS takes accessability seriously. Accessability guidelines presented in this section MUST be followed if new elements are added.

subCategories.title: Less
subCategories.description: ILIAS uses less as css pre-processor. This section introduces all used less variables and guidelines of less.

subCategories.title: Grid
subCategories.description: Bootstrap includes a responsive, mobile first fluid grid system that appropriately scales up to 12 columns as the device or viewport size increases. It includes predefined classes for easy layout options, as well as powerful mixins for generating more semantic layouts. In ILIAS the Bootstrap Grid MUST be used for all arrangements of components in a grid like structure.

itemGroups.title: Containers
itemGroups.description: All rows must be placed inside a container

items.title: Default
items.description: Rows must be placed within a .container (fixed-width) or .container-fluid (full-width) for proper alignment and padding.
items.context: Use a container as outer element, wherever to boostrap grid system is to be used.

items.title: Fluid
items.description: All rows of the grid system must be placed within a .container (fixed-width) or .container-fluid (full-width) for proper alignment and padding.
items.context: Turn any fixed-width grid layout into a full-width layout by changing your outermost .container to .container-fluid. There should only be one fluid container in the DOM of ILIAS.

itemGroups.title: Rows
itemGroups.description: Rows are used to create horizontal groups of columns

items.title: Default
items.description: Rows are used to create horizontal groups of columns.
items.context: Rows MUST be placed inside a container

items.title: Default
items.description: Columns create gutters (gaps between column content) via padding. That padding is offset in rows for the first and last column via negative margin on .rows. Grid columns are created by specifying the number of twelve available columns you wish to span. For example, three equal columns would use three .col-xs-4. Grid classes apply to devices with screen widths greater than or equal to the breakpoint sizes, and override grid classes targeted at smaller devices. Therefore, e.g. applying any .col-md-* class to an element will not only affect its styling on medium devices but also on large devices if a .col-lg-* class is not present.
items.context: Columns MUST be placed inside a row

subCategories.title: Buttons
subCategories.description: Description of this sub Category

items.title: Button
items.description: Buttons are either of an input elemen (with some cmd) or or a link (with some href). So far ILIAS does not support the <button> type.
items.context: Use buttons to initiate an action of some sort. If an action is temporarily not available, actions (buttons) might be disabled by setting as type 'disabled'.

items.title: Default
items.description: Default Button in ILIAS. Buttons are either of type input (with some cmd) or link (with some href).
items.context: This is the most commonly used button instance in ILIAS and should be used, whenever there is not a good reason to use a special instance.

items.title: Primary
items.description: The 'Primary Button' is special emphasized button that marks to most important action on a view. There should only be one 'Primary Button' per page and each use must be confirmed by the JF. In Toolbars primary actions will be sticky, meaning they will not be disappear in the responsive view.
items.context: According to Emphasized Buttons for Primary Action 'Buttons for a common and important next action that tend to be overlooked, should get a special emphasized style'. This style is currently named as 'Primary Button'.

subCategories.title: Navigation
subCategories.description: Elements used to navigate.

items.title: Breadcrumb
items.context: Breadcrumbs MUST be displayed in the realm of the RBAC.

subCategories.title: Forms
subCategories.description: Types of forms and form items to be used in ILIAS

items.title: Base Form
items.description: A form is divided into area which are further divided into sections. Each form MUST have a header and a footer section containing the buttons to save or cancel the input of the form.
items.context: A form SHOULD be used whenever data input is needed from the user.

items.title: Form Area
items.context: Each form MUST contain at least one area.

items.title: Form Section
items.context: An area of a form MUST at least contain one section. Ideally the SHOULD contain between 2 and 5 sections. A section might also contain a subform that can be triggered by either checkbox or a combobox.

items.title: Subform
items.description: Sections might contain complete forms called subforms. Subforms are special forms.
items.context: Subforms are made visible by enabling either a checkbox or an option in a combobox

items.title: Form Element
items.description: Form elements are used to get input from the user. Depending on the type of input, a different type of form element is needed. Check among the different categories of input type to find the best fitting form element of all available choices.
items.context: Each section contains exactly one form element.

items.title: Form Footer
items.description: The footer encloses the form. It holds a description of the identifier for mandatory fields and contains the save (left) and cancel (right) button to store or drop changes.
items.context: Each form MUST contain a footer section.

items.title: Checkbox
items.description: Box that has either status 'checked' or 'unchecked'. A checkbox is used to govern a state, action, or value that can either be on or off. The checkbox MUST always state something positive.
items.context: A checkbox MUST be used if a binary choice (E.g. yes or no) is asked for. You MUST NOT use two radio buttons or a drop-down list with two choices for scenario.

items.title: Date Time picker
items.description: Form item to pick a date and/or time.
items.context: Use whenever a date or/and time is needed from the user.

items.title: Date Time Range Picker
items.description: Form item to let the user pick a date/time range.
items.context: Use where are range From - To is needed. Often used in filters.

items.title: File Upload
items.description: Current version of the File Upload.

subCategories.description: A dialog is an application window that is designed to interrupt the current processing of an application in order to prompt the user to enter information or require a response.

subCategories.title: Actions
subCategories.description: Components used to initiate actions of some sort. Other components used for navigation, those components to no just redirect to user to some other part of the application, but actually let the user manipulate the data.

items.title: Toolbar
items.description: Complete description to be found at: http://www.ilias.de/docu/goto_docu_frm_3814_3100.html

subCategories.title: Callouts
subCategories.description: Callouts give the user easily visible feedback of some sort.

subCategories.title: Containers
subCategories.description: Containers build a frame around other components. They group items to make them easy to identify as cluster.

subCategories.title: Main Structure
subCategories.description: Main skeleton of the ILIAS Dom structure

items.title: Overview
items.description: The main layout of the ILIAS Page contains three sections: the header section, the content section and the footer section.

items.title: Overview
items.description: Overview of the ILIAS header area.

items.title: Branding
items.description: The branding area SHOULD contain the logo of the application and its title.

items.title: Main Menu
items.description: The main menu handles the main navigation in ILIAS.

items.title: Top Nav
items.description: The Top Nav area holds links and dropdowns for search, user specific action such as logout/login, settings, mail etc. It should be placed at the top right of the screen.

items.title: Overview
items.description: The content section is devided into a left and right sidebar and the center content. Between those ist empty space. Important, the current example is only a very raw draft. JS logic is done by the UI-Kitchen-Sink via angularJS. The example presented bellow is therefore only static. See the sidebars of the Kitchen-Sink for a working example.

items.title: Center Content
items.description: The content section is devided into a left and right sidebar and the center content. Between those ist empty space. Important, the current example is only a very raw draft. JS logic is done by the UI-Kitchen-Sink via angularJS. The example presented bellow is therefore only static. See the sidebars of the Kitchen-Sink for a working example.

items.title: Sidebars
items.description: The right sidebar could be used to provide the user meta-information about ILIAS such as mail, global calendar, help, tree etc.. The right sidebar could be used to provide content specific meta information such as tags, comments etc..
items.context: The sidebars are accessible at all time.

items.title: Overview
items.description: The footer mostly displays some meta information about the page.

subCategories.title: Center Stage
subCategories.description: A big central stage in the middle of the content.

subCategories.title: Drilldown
subCategories.description: When the user selects an item from the list, show the details or contents of that item in the window, replacing the list.

subCategories.title: Carousel
subCategories.description: Arrange a list of visually interesting items into a horizontal strip or arc, and let the user scroll or swipe the image thumbnails back and forth to view them. Enlarge the center item, if appropriate.
